Directions
In a large bowl, whisk together buckwheat flour, all-purpose flour, baking powder, and salt to combine. Add water and whisk until a smooth batter with the consistency of half-and-half forms. Let sit until slightly thickened and bubbly, about 10 minutes.
Serious Eats / Melati Citrawireja
Meanwhile, adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 200°F (90°C). Set a wire rack in a rimmed baking sheet and transfer to oven.
Serious Eats / Melati Citrawireja
Preheat a 10-inch cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat until hot, 3 to 4 minutes. (If your pan is well-seasoned, then no cooking oil will be necessary; if it's not, add 1/2 teaspoon neutral oil to the pan as it heats and use a wadded up paper towel to spread it into a then layer before proceeding with the recipe.)
Whisk batter to recombine. Using a 1/4-cup dry measuring cup
,
pour one 1/4 cup portion of batter into center of skillet. Using the bottom of measuring cup or back of a metal ladle, spread batter into a very thin circle, about 7 inches in diameter.
Serious Eats / Melati Citrawireja
Cook until holes form and batter sets, top is dry with edges beginning to curl, and bottom is golden brown and crisp, 1 to 2 minutes. Use a spatula to transfer to wire rack in oven to keep warm or serving plate to serve immediately. Repeat cooking with remaining batter. You should have 12 ployes. Serve with your preferred sweet or savory accompaniments, such as butter, maple syrup, berries, cretons, or meats.
Serious Eats / Melati Citrawireja
Special Equipment
Whisk, rimmed baking sheet, wire rack, 10-inch cast iron skillet or griddle, 1/4-cup dry measuring cup, spatula
Notes
I recommend using Maine-grown light buckwheat from growers like Bouchard Family Farms or Maine Grains. If you substitute with other buckwheat flour, the ployes will be a dark purplish-brown color rather than yellow, and the pancakes will have a stronger buckwheat flavor.
